page.title: 01LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: This area is predominantly a sector of the valley of the River Nidd,the smallest of the tributaries of the Ouse. It is mostly pastureland as the climate is too wet for the growing of crops, although about 19% of the area is original woodland. A millstone grit crag, Guisecliffe dominates the central section, with its steep northerly slope still covered in trees, and above it to the south wild open moorland. The northern side of the valley has a gentler slope and is divided with small dairy farms, although smaller patches of woodland still remain. The original settlement was of scattered hamlets and farms such as Wilsill and Braisty, but in the nineteenth century several industrial hamlets grew up around water-powered flax, later hemp, mills.
